contextId.information: The sinners speak of murdering innocent people as if they were Sheol and they would take a living and healthy person down to the place where dead people go. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let us swallow them up alive, like Sheol takes away those who are healthy

contextId.information: Here a person's behavior is spoken of as if it were a way or road. Also, a person receiving the results of their behavior is spoken as if the person were eating the fruit of their behavior. AT: "experience the consequences of their actions" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: eat the fruit of their ways

contextId.information: A person rejecting wisdom is spoken of as if the person physically turns away from wisdom. This can be stated in active form. AT: "die because they refuse to learn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: are killed when they turn away

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) justice itself is spoken of as if it were a path. AT: "God makes sure that people act justly" or 2) a person's life is spoken of as if it were a path. AT: "God protects those who act justly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he guards the paths of justice

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person's opinion as if that person were seeing something with his eyes. AT: "Do not be wise in your own opinion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Do not be wise in your own eyes

contextId.information: The writer speaks of "wisdom" as if it were an object that one finds. AT: "The one who attains wisdom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The one who finds wisdom

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh creating the earth and the heavens as if he were laying the foundation of a building. AT: "Yahweh created the earth ... made the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh founded the earth ... established the heavens

contextId.information: The writer speaks of living one's life as if the person were walking along a path. AT: "you will live your life in safety" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will walk on your way in safety

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh's curse as if it were an object that he placed on top of the wicked person's house. The word "house" is a metonym for family. AT: "Yahweh has cursed the family of the wicked person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The curse of Yahweh is on the house of the wicked person

contextId.information: The writer speaks of wise people obtaining a reputation of honor as if they inherited honor as a permanent possession. AT: "Wise people will obtain honor" or "Wise people will gain an honorable reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Wise people inherit honor

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person remembering what he has learned as if "instruction" were an object that the person can hold tightly. AT: "Continue to obey what I have taught you and never forget it" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Hold on to instruction, do not let it go

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the actions and lifestyles of righteous people and wicked people as if they were a "path" or "way" upon which they walk. AT: "the lifestyle of righteous people ... The lifestyle of the wicked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the path of righteous people ... The way of the wicked

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the harm that comes from having a relationship with an adulteress as if she tasted as bitter as wormwood. AT: "but in the end, she is like bitter-tasting wormwood and will cause you harm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but in the end she is as bitter as wormwood

contextId.information: The writer speaks of behavior that gives a person long life as if it were a path that leads to life. AT: "She does not think about walking along the path that leads to life" or "She is not concerned about conduct that leads to life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: She gives no thought to the path of life

contextId.information: The writer speaks of people taking and enjoying another person's wealth as if they were feasting on the wealth. AT: "strangers will not take all of your wealth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: strangers will not feast on your wealth

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the son's wife as if she were a fountain. Here the word "blessed" refers to the sense of joy that the man has in his wife. AT: "May you always find joy with your wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: May your fountain be blessed

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the son's wife as if she were "a loving deer and a graceful doe." Here "deer" and "doe" mean a female deer. They were symbols of beauty both in their appearance and in their movements. AT: "she is as beautiful and graceful as a deer or a doe" or "she is as beautiful and graceful as a female deer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she is a loving deer and a graceful doe

contextId.information: All three of these mean basically the same thing and are repeated to emphasize the fact that the lessons make life better and easier. AT: "as useful as a lamp ... as helpful as light in the darkness ... as necessary to follow as the way of life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: a lamp ... a light ... the way of life

contextId.information: Here keeping represents obeying. AT: "obey my words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: keep my words

contextId.information: Here the pleasures of romantic love are spoken of as if they were something good to drink. AT: "let us make love to each other as much as we want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let us drink our fill of love

contextId.information: To persuade someone to act in a certain way is spoken of as if it were changing the direction that person was walking. AT: "she persuaded him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she turned him

contextId.information: Here "ways" means the paths that a person chooses to walk on. It represents the person's behavior, the things that he decides to do in life. AT: "Make your heart stay far away from the ways of the adulterous woman" or "Do not let your heart want to do the things that the adulterous woman does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: May your heart not turn aside onto her paths

contextId.information: Living the right way is spoken of as walking on the right road. AT: "I live right" or "I do what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I walk in the path of righteousness

contextId.information: These terms normally refer to the money a worker earns. Here they represents the results of either doing what is right or doing what is wrong. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The wage ... the profit

contextId.information: A game is an activity people do for pleasure. AT: "Fools find pleasure in wickedness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Wickedness is a game a fool plays

contextId.information: "Scales" represent measuring accurately in negotiating. AT: "God hates deceiving scales" or "God hates it when people are deceitful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh hates scales that are not accurate

contextId.information: "Sowing seed" represents preparing for the future. AT: "a person who prepares for the future" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: one who sows seed

contextId.information: The "wind" is something that cannot be grasped. AT: "inherit nothing." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: inherit the wind

contextId.information: The deceitful things that wicked people say in order to harm other people are spoken of as if their words are waiting to kill someone by surprise. AT: "The deceitful things wicked people say are like a person who waits to kill someone by surprise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The words of wicked people are an ambush waiting for a chance to kill

contextId.information: "Weighing down" represents the idea of putting a very heavy load on a person so he cannot move freely. This phrase means to make a person sad or depressed. AT: "causes him to become sad or depressed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: weighs him down

contextId.information: "Walks" represents the conduct of life. AT: "conducts his life in a just and honest way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: walks uprightly

contextId.information: The word "heart" represents a person's feelings, attitudes and motivations. AT: "A person's feelings can show laughter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A heart can laugh

contextId.information: The word "ways" represents a person's conduct of life. AT: "what he deserves, based on how he lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what his ways deserve

contextId.information: The word "crown" represents the highest achievement possible and visible to all. AT: "The reward of wise people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The crown of wise people

contextId.information: A "fountain" is a bountiful source of water and represents here the source of life. AT: "source of life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: fountain of life

contextId.information: Causing a person to stop being angry is spoken of as if it were turning that person's wrath away. AT: "Answering a person gently will calm that person's wrath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A gentle answer turns away wrath

contextId.information: The word "lips" represents what wise people say. The writer speaks of knowledge as if it were seeds that wise people scatter around when they speak. AT: "The speech of wise people spreads knowledge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The lips of wise people scatter knowledge about

contextId.information: The lifestyles of wicked people are spoken of as if they are paths on which those people walk. AT: "Yahweh hates the way that wicked people live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh hates the way of wicked people

contextId.information: Here "the way" refers to the way of righteousness. A person who stops doing what is right is spoken of as if he has stopped walking on the correct path. AT: "anyone who stops living rightly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: anyone who forsakes the way

contextId.information: Causing people to argue more is spoken of as if it were stirring up or awakening arguments. AT: "causes people to argue more" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: stirs up arguments

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person's life as if it were a path on which the person walks. AT: "The life of the sluggard ... the life of the upright" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The path of the sluggard ... the path of the upright

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a lifestyle that results in life as if it were a path that goes upward towards life and of a lifestyle that results in death as if it were a path that leads down to the place of the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The path of life leads upward ... from Sheol beneath

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Yahweh not listening to wicked people as if he were physically far away from them. AT: "Yahweh does not listen to wicked people" or "Yahweh does not answer wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh is far away from wicked people

contextId.information: The writer speaks of an angry king causing someone to die as if the king's wrath were a messenger that he sends out to kill someone. AT: "An angry king can put people to death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A king's wrath is a messenger of death

contextId.information: The writer speaks of an expression of joy on the king's face as if his face emitted light. AT: "When the king is cheerful, people live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: In the light of a king's face is life

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the lifestyle of upright people as if it were a well-built road, free of obstacles. AT: "The righteous way that upright people live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The highway of upright people

contextId.information: The writer speaks of "Understanding" as if it were a fountain that continuously flows with water and which sustains the life of those who drink from it. AT: "Understanding is like a fountain flowing with life-giving water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Understanding is a fountain of life

contextId.information: The writer speaks of pleasant words being able to bring delight to the hearers as if the words were a honeycomb dripping with fresh honey. AT: "Pleasant words are like a honeycomb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pleasant words are a honeycomb

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person trying to find ways to harm other people as if that person were digging in the ground to find something buried. AT: "A worthless person looks for mischief as if he were digging for something in the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A worthless person digs up mischief

contextId.information: The writer speaks of gray hair as if it were a crown. "Gray hair" is a metonym for old age. AT: "A person who has lived long enough to have gray hair is like one who wears a glorious crown on his head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Gray hair is a crown of glory

contextId.information: This speaks of older peoples' grandchildren being a sign of honor for them as if their grandchildren were a crown. AT: "bring honor and respect to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: are the crown of

contextId.information: This compares how a rebuke effects a man of understanding to how a beating effects a fool. This speaks of the effect on these people as if it could be measured by the depth that it goes into them. AT: "A rebuke has more effect on a person ... than a hundred blows have on a fool" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A rebuke goes deeper into a person ... than a hundred blows go into a fool

contextId.information: This speaks of a cheerful heart as being good medicine because it makes you feel better. AT: "A cheerful heart is like medicine that makes you feel better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: A cheerful heart is good medicine

contextId.information: This speaks of a person's focus on acting wisely as if he were looking at wisdom. AT: "focuses on acting wisely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sets his face toward wisdom

contextId.information: This speaks of Yahweh protecting his people as if he were a strong tower in which they could take refuge. AT: "Yahweh protects like a strong tower" or "Yahweh protects his people like a strong tower" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The name of Yahweh is a strong tower

contextId.information: This speaks of a rich person depending on his wealth as if his wealth were a fortified wall that protects him. AT: "The wealthy person depends on his wealth as a city depends on its fortified wall" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The wealth of the rich is his fortified city

contextId.information: This speaks of the difficulty of making peace with a brother you have offended by comparing it to the difficulty of winning a war against a strong city. AT: "If you offend your brother, finding a way to have peace with him again may be harder than waging a battle to win a city" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: An offended brother is harder to be won than a strong city

contextId.information: This speaks of a person being satisfied or content by the result of what they have said as if they had eaten and become satisfied" AT: "a person is satisfied" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: one's stomach is filled

contextId.information: Yahweh considers kindness shown to the poor to be kindness shown to him. One of the ways people are kind to the poor is by giving. AT: "The person who gives to the poor is giving to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Whoever is kind to the poor lends to Yahweh

contextId.information: A person who God considers spiritually acceptable is spoken of as if the person where physically clean. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: clean

contextId.information: This speaks of something being dangerous as if it were a trap or a snare. AT: "It is dangerous" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It is a snare

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the king's heart as if it were an irrigation ditch in a dry area through which people direct water to plants that need it. AT: "Yahweh controls the king's heart as a man directs water for irrigation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The king's heart is a stream of water in the hand of Yahweh

contextId.information: The word "ransom" is a metaphor for one person who takes the place of another person. Here the person who does what is wrong is punished instead of the person who does what is right. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is ransom for

contextId.information: The writer speaks of the way perverse people live as if it were a path on which the perverse will have trouble because of the natural "thorns" and man-made "snares." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Thorns and snares lie in the path of the perverse

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a ruler or other powerful person treating those less powerful unjustly as if he were planting seeds that will give birth to plants that bring trouble. AT: "If a person treats those less powerful than he is unjustly, they will cause him trouble later on" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He who sows injustice will reap trouble

contextId.information: The metaphor is of a lawyer defending the needy in front of a judge. AT: "Yahweh will defend the needy from those who oppress them" or "Yahweh will see that the needy receive justice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will plead their case

contextId.information: someone who is unable to control his anger (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: someone who is ruled by anger

contextId.information: land like a bird upon the wealth (verse 4). This is a metaphor for looking at the wealth for a short time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: light upon it

contextId.information: The word "it" refers to "the wine when it is red." "Bites" and "stings" are metaphors for the way too much wine makes people feel. AT: "it makes you feel as bad as if a serpent had bitten you or an adder had stung you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: it bites like a serpent ... it stings like an adder

contextId.information: Snow only fell on the tops of mountains, and the harvest took place in hot weather, so this is probably a metaphor for cool, fresh water from a clean stream. If your language has no word for snow, consider "cool, fresh, clean water." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the cold of snow

contextId.information: Disguising his feelings represents keeping people from knowing what his feelings are. The phrase "his lips" is a metonym for what he says. AT: "hides his feelings with what he says" or "speaks in such a way that people cannot know his true feelings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: disguises his feelings with his lips

contextId.information: Keeping people from knowing that he hates them is spoken of as covering his hatred. AT: "Though he lies to keep people from knowing that he hates them" or "Though he lies so that people will not know that he hates them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Though his hatred is covered with deception

contextId.information: "the destructiveness of anger." Anger is spoken of here as if it were a powerful flood. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the flood of anger

contextId.information: "The wounds that a friend causes are trustworthy." The word "wounds" here represents the pain and sadness that a person feels when a friend rebukes or corrects him.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Faithful are the wounds caused by a friend

contextId.information: This means that even if a fool is made to suffer hardship or pain (being crushed is often a metaphor for suffering in Hebrew), he will remain foolish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Even if you crush a fool ... yet his foolishness will not leave him

contextId.information: This represents a person living a life of integrity. The abstract noun "integrity" can be expressed as an adverb. AT: "walks honestly" or "lives honestly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: walks in his integrity

contextId.information: To "keep the law" means to do what God's law requires. AT: "He who obeys God's law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He who keeps the law

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for leading upright people in an evil direction. AT: "Whoever causes the upright to go in an evil direction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Whoever misleads the upright into an evil way

contextId.information: "covers his sins." This is the opposite of confessing and forsaking sins, and is spoken of as covering sins rather than bringing them into the open (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hides his sins

contextId.information: This represents a person living a life of integrity. The abstract noun "integrity" can be expressed as an adverb. AT: "walks honestly" or "lives honestly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: walks with integrity

contextId.information: The action of the greedy man is spoken of as if he were stirring up or awakening conflict. AT: "causes conflict" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: stirs up conflict

contextId.information: Causing people to argue more is spoken of as if it were stirring up or awakening arguments. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:pro:15:17|15:18]]. AT: "causes people to argue more" or "causes people to argue and fight." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: stirs up strife

contextId.information: Being afraid of what other people might do is spoken of as stepping into a trap. AT: "Anyone who is afraid of what other people might do to him is like a person who has become snared in a trap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The fear of man makes a snare

contextId.information: Words are spoken of as if they were metals that need someone to clean the bad parts out of them. AT: "is like a precious metal from which someone has removed all the useless material" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: is tested

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "Do not allow people to speak vanity and lies to me" or 2) "Do not allow me to speak vanity and lies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Put vanity and lies far away from me

contextId.information: This is an example of something that always wants more. AT: "Greed has two daughters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The leech has two daughters

contextId.information: The "heart" refers to the middle. AT: "in the middle of the sea" or "on the open sea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in the heart of the sea

contextId.information: The money she has earned from the work she did with wool and flax ([[:en:bible:notes:pro:31:13|31:13]]) is spoken of as if it were fruit growing off a tree. The hands are a synecdoche for the person. AT: "the money she has earned" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the fruit of her hands

contextId.information: This can be translated in active form. The abstract nouns "strength" and "honor" can be translated by an adjective and a verb, respectively. AT: "Everyone can see that she is strong, and so they honor her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: She is clothed with strength and honor

contextId.information: The word "ways" refers to the way people live. AT: "makes sure her whole family lives in a way that pleases God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: watches over the ways of her household
